Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Frequent timeouts when establishing a connection to api-v2v3search-0.nuget.org" (#5899) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Closed issue "Securing a gallery so that authentication is required to access packages" (#5800) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
I have searched the issues and the web for this and I am not finding any good answers. I would like to secure my NuGetGallery such that authentication is always required. One of my sources has done this by providing us with a special URL to access their nuget feed.

https://nuget.{vendor}.com/{API Key?}/api

I have about decided that they are running a custom build of the server. What would be the best way to implement something like this, or where would the easiest place be to implement this?

I would like my nuget server to behave like below:


https://nuget.{my company}.com/{API Key?}/api -> pulls packages like normal
https://nuget.{my company}.com/api -> 401 Unauthorized or 404 Not Found
https://nuget.{my company}.com/{API Key?} -> homepage like normal
https://nuget.{my company}.com/ -> login page then to homepage

Edit:
It is possible that I can have another piece of software extract the API key from the url and put it into a request header if having the auth key in the header is easier to do.

Thanks in advance for any guidance you can provide.
Regards,
Texernie

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "Versions show very few characters in package details page when using semver2.0.0 versions" (#5893) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8865080/39716275-b9f70eac-51e4-11e8-9829-e08e7c32d219.png)

Looking at NuGet.Packaging, any packages with prerelease labels in their version, don't show up very well on NuGet gallery.
See attached picture.

4.8.0-previe... (current version)
4.7.0-rtm...
4.70.-rtm...
4.7.0-previe...
4.7.0-previe...

This is likely because we have SemVer 2.0.0 names --- i'd imagine we could show more of the version string...the useful part.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Certificates:  hide UI behind feature flag" (#5886) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Closed issue "Certificates:  displaysdropdown for non-editable signing owner when package has single owner" (#5882) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Merged pull request "Dev to Master" (#5898) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Reopened issue "Certificates:  require 2FA for changes" (#5775) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Reopened issue "Certificates:  bugs" (#5868) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
* Although `DefaultDependenciesModule` was configured to create one `CertificateService` instance per request, `StorageDependent` was configured to create `CertificateService` as a singleton.  This results in being able to register the same certificate multiple times.
* The size of the (pink) validation error region in the Certificates section of account settings is too big.
* When an HTTP error (>= 500) occurs in the Certificates section of account settings, an error isn't displayed.
* Signing information is repeated for all package versions
* There are minor page layout issues.

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "Certificates:  enable certificate registration in Gallery" (#5634) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
* certificate registration should be available from both user and organization account settings
* filter file extensions to .cer and .crt
* limit file upload size to 10 KB and warn if limit exceeded
* generate fingerprints (SHA-1 and SHA-256) server side
* upload certificate to blob storage
* add tests

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "Certificates:  more bugs from bug bash" (#5873) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
* Package validation errors need updating.
* When package has single owner, the signing owner on the manage packages page should not only show the signing owner's user name, but also how many certificates they have (e.g.:  "`user1 (1 certificate)`" vs. "`user1`").
* The `AutomaticallyOverwriteRequiredSignerPolicy` policy should trigger even if the new owner has no certificates.
* The  `AutomaticallyOverwriteRequiredSignerPolicy` policy triggered if the new owner was a user but not an organization.
* The 2FA warning message should be different if 2FA is enabled but a password was used.

3.  Try installing it:
```
C:\>NuGet.exe install E2E.SignedPackage -Version 2018.5.4-v165750 -DirectDownload -NoCache -Source https://apidev.nugettest.org/v3-index/index.json -OutputDirectory C:\packages
Feeds used:
  https://apidev.nugettest.org/v3-index/index.json

Retrieving package 'MicroBuild.Core 0.3.0' from 'https://apidev.nugettest.org/v3-index/index.json'.
  GET https://apidev.nugettest.org/v3-flatcontainer/microbuild.core/0.3.0/microbuild.core.0.3.0.nupkg
  GET https://apidev.nugettest.org/v3-flatcontainer/e2e.signedpackage/2018.5.4-v165750/e2e.signedpackage.2018.5.4-v165750.nupkg

Adding package 'MicroBuild.Core.0.3.0' to folder 'C:\packages'
WARNING: Install failed. Rolling back...
Executing nuget actions took 822.38 ms
NU3000:
```

The DEV environment is currently misconfigured.  As of writing this, the DEV environment [declares](https://apidev.nugettest.org/v3-index/repository-signatures/index.json) that all packages are repository signed with either of two certificates.  Not all packages in the DEV environment are repository signed.  So when installing the main package, which is only author signed, and its dependency, which is unsigned, signature validation fails.

I expect to see a unique NuGet log code for this scenario with something like:

    '{PackageRepository}' declared that all its packages are repository signed; however, package '{PackageIdentity}' was not signed with an expected certificate and is blocked from install.

Events.RelatedBody:
Remove the content above here and fill out details below.

## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe):

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx):
4.6.2.5055
dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate):

VS version (if appropriate):
15.2


OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)):
win10
Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version:

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem



1. create nuget package for Web API project
nuget pack -Symbols –IncludeReferencedProjects –Exclude **\*.asax

2. Install said nuget package in another web api project

Result is that the first binding redirect in the web.config becomes gets modified in an incorrect way (see result below) and causes run time errors. I believe the result is that binding redirect for that package gets lost giving the following error:

Could not load file or assembly 'Newtonsoft.Json, Version=6.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=30ad4fe6b2a6aeed' or one of its dependencies. The located assembly's manifest definition does not match the assembly reference. (Exception from HRESULT: 0x80131040)


Before installing nuget package
<dependentAssembly>
        <assemblyIdentity name="Newtonsoft.Json" publicKeyToken="30ad4fe6b2a6aeed" culture="neutral" />
        <bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-11.0.0.0" newVersion="11.0.0.0" />
      </dependentAssembly>


after installing nuget package
 <dependentAssembly>
        <assemblyIdentity name="Newtonsoft.Json" publicKeyToken="30ad4fe6b2a6aeed" culture="neutral" />
        <bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-11.0.0.0" newVersion="11.0.0.0" />

        <assemblyIdentity name="System.Web.WebPages" publicKeyToken="31bf3856ad364e35" />
        <bindingRedirect oldVersion="1.0.0.0-3.0.0.0" newVersion="3.0.0.0" />
        <assemblyIdentity name="System.Web.Http" publicKeyToken="31bf3856ad364e35" culture="neutral" />

        <assemblyIdentity name="Microsoft.Owin" publicKeyToken="31bf3856ad364e35" culture="neutral" />
        <bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-4.0.0.0" newVersion="4.0.0.0" />
      </dependentAssembly>

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Signing:  SignedPackageVerifierSettings.VSClientDefaultPolicy is unused" (#6601) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: [`SignedPackageVerifierSettings.VSClientDefaultPolicy`](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/e2fb49fed454bcdd48c53efcb40ba26a50be761e/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Packaging/Signing/Verification/SignedPackageVerifierSettings.cs#L72) is not used anywhere. Opened issue "NuGet.org API rate limits for package updates" (#24) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
|Spec wiki|Discussion issue|
|----------|------------------|
|*None*|https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4679|

We have been working on improving the package submission workflow to reduce the overall time it takes to publish the package (right from package push/upload) till it's available for consumption and search. 

As mentioned on our [blog post](https://blog.nuget.org/20180201/NuGet-package-publishing-workflow-behind-the-scenes.html), the package availability gets degraded multi fold whenever there is a large number package uploads/updates by a single owner that clogs the package submission pipeline. Until we are able to scale to handle the large submission rate, in the short-term, we plan to reduce the rate limits for package pushes or deletes (unlist) per user.

The current [documented rate limits](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/api/rate-limits#package-push-and-unlist) will be updated to the following new limits once implemented. This change will go live, **soon** (within a week or two):

## Package Push and Unlist

| API | Limit Type | Limit Value | API usecase | 
|:---|:---|:---|:--- |
**PUT** `/api/v2/package` | API Key | ~~100 / minute~~ **250 / hour** | Upload a new NuGet package (version) via v2 push endpoint 
**DELETE** `/api/v2/package/{id}/{version}` | API Key | ~~100 / minute~~ **50 / hour** | Unlist a NuGet package (version) via v2 endpoint
